727053f-a.text:
(1)

Jamaica Avenue, south side, between New York Boulevard, and 165th Street, showing Colonial Hall, now the Queensboro Public Library.  The original building, known as the Union Hall Academy for boys, was erected in 1792 and used as such until 1820 when a new building for the academy was erected on the west side of Union Hall Street, just north of the Long Island Railroad tracks.  The original building became a female Seminary under the trustees of the Union Hall Academy and was destroyed by fire on Febhruary 12, 1841.  The cornerstone of the building in this view was laid on March 11, 1843 and the seminary was reopened in May of that year and was still used as such in 1876.  This structure was subsequently owned by ex-sheriff Welliam Cass Baker who had it remodeled in 1897 when it became known as Colonial Hall.  It was then used as a public hall and club rooms, subsequently becoming a family hotel and rooming house.  In 1922 one of the branches of the Queensboro Public Library occupied it; it was razed in May 1923.  On its site is now located the Stuart Building.

1891

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

(2), (3)

The same, years later.

1922

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

726976f-b.text:
Jamaica Avenue, at the S.W. corner of New York Boulevard, showing the former Van Wyck house, now occupied by a drygoods store. The house was a Methodist Episcopal church from 1873 to 1876 and was erected in 1846. The owner of the structure in 1891 was J.B. Hopkins.
Views 1,2: 1922
View 3: 1923
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

727095f-a.text:
Jamaica Ave., at the N.E. corner of 222nd Street, showing the W.R. Thaylor house of 1891. To the right of it is seen the Albertson house.

April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

726975f-a.text:
Jamaica Avenue, east from New York Boulevard, showing the elevated structure of the B.M.T. subway system thereon and Jamaica's business district. Next to the modernistic Kurtz Building is the Merrick Theatre and the Stuart Building. Across the rooftops (left) is the First Presbyterian church steeple.
P. L. Sperr  April 1, 1932

727094f-a.text:
Jamaica Ave., south side, west from 222nd St. (formerly Madison Ave.), showing the home of A. W. Wood.

April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

727471f-b.text:
New York Boulevard, west side (former No. 32), between the Long Island Railroad and Jamaica Ave., showing the Daniel Smith residence of 1873;he erected the Town Hall of Jamaica. View No. 2 shows a view of the upper floors of the house as seen from
the Long Island Railroad station.
1922.
View 21 May 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
